docs.title: Conventions
docs.text: This documentation use some symbols and icons located at the top of articles for illustration and enhanced documentation. To fully leverage thisc content please make you are familliar with these conventions.

docs.title: – Experimental
docs.text: We may offer beta features for you to test and try out. These features are still being refined and might occasionally change based on feedback, though we aim to keep them stable and available for your use.

docs.title: – Swagger
docs.text: This symbol is used to provide link to Open API documentation allowing you to try API assuming you have valid credentials.

docs.title: – Example repository
docs.text: This symbol provides a link to specific repository containing runnable located on Github.

docs.title: – Notebook
docs.text: This symbol provides a link to runnable notebook of the feature or the analytic located on Github.--8<-- "snippets/contact-footer.md"

docs.title: NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)
docs.text: Index that measures vegetation health based on visible and near-infrared light reflectance. Values range from -1 to 1, with higher values indicating denser, healthier vegetation.

docs.title: LR images
docs.text: Image resolutions: MR (Medium Resolution) and LR (Low Resolution). Define the spatial detail level of the NDVI data used.

docs.title: MR images
docs.text: Medium Resolution imagery are satellite optical images with a resolution ranging from 10m to 30m.

docs.title: Season Duration
docs.text: Duration of the crop season, in days, used to calculate cumulative NDVI.

docs.title: Season Start Day / Month
docs.text: Day and month marking the beginning of the crop season. Define the starting point for NDVI accumulation.

docs.title: Threshold
docs.text: NDVI value used as a cutoff to determine relevant vegetative activity.

docs.title: End Date
docs.text: Date until which the in-season NDVI is accumulated.

docs.title: Potential Score
docs.text: Indicator of the productive potential of an area based on cumulative NDVI during the season.

docs.title: Historical Potential Score
docs.text: Mean of potential scores from previous seasons.

docs.title: In-season Potential Score
docs.text: Cumulative NDVI-based score for the current season up to the specified end date.

docs.title: Relative Potential Score
docs.text: Ratio (in %) of in-season score to historical potential score.

docs.title: WKT (Well-Known Text)
docs.text: Standard format for representing spatial geometries such as polygons, points, and lines.

docs.title: AOI (Area of Interest)
docs.text: User-defined area for analysis. Usually defined as WKT.

docs.title: ESPG code
docs.text: EPSG codes are numerical codes associated with coordinate system definitions. For example, the EPSG code: 4326 matches with WGS84 geographical projection and is commonly used.

docs.title: CAR (Cadastro Ambiental Rural)
docs.text: Brazilian national public registry integrating environmental information about rural properties, including farm boundaries and environmental features.

docs.title: INCRA (Instituto Nacional de Colonização e Reforma Agrária)
docs.text: Federal agency responsible for land reform, land management, and maintaining Brazilian national land databases such as SIGEF and SNCI.

docs.title: IBAMA (Instituto Brasileiro do Meio Ambiente e dos Recursos Naturais Renováveis)
docs.text: Federal environmental agency in charge of environmental law enforcement, licensing, and conservation at the national level.

docs.title: ICMBio (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade)
docs.text: Federal agency responsible for managing Brazil's conservation units and biodiversity preservation.

docs.title: SEMA-MT (Secretaria de Estado de Meio Ambiente de Mato Grosso)
docs.text: State Secretariat for the Environment in Mato Grosso, responsible for environmental regulation and enforcement.

docs.title: SEMA (Secretaria de Estado de Meio Ambiente)
docs.text: State-level Secretariat for the Environment (generic term; each state may have its own, e.g., SEMA-MT).

docs.title: SIGA-GO (Sistema de Gestão Ambiental de Goiás)
docs.text: State environmental management system for Goiás, used to track infractions, embargoes, and environmental compliance.

docs.title: SIGA-MT (Sistema Integrado de Gestão Ambiental de Mato Grosso)
docs.text: State environmental management system for Mato Grosso.

docs.title: IAT-PR (Instituto Água e Terra do Paraná)
docs.text: Environmental institute of Paraná responsible for licensing, monitoring, and conservation activities.

docs.title: LDI-PA (Lista de Desmatamento Ilegal do Pará)
docs.text: Official list of farms with illegal deforestation in the state of Pará.

docs.title: SNCI (Sistema Nacional de Cadastro de Imóveis Rurais)
docs.text: National Property Certification System developed by INCRA to manage cadastral and geospatial data of rural properties.

docs.title: SIGEF (Sistema de Gestão Fundiária)
docs.text: Land Management System developed by INCRA to register and validate georeferenced rural property data.

docs.title: CPF (Cadastro de Pessoa Física)
docs.text: Brazilian individual taxpayer registry number issued by the Federal Revenue Service. Used to identify natural persons.

docs.title: CNPJ (Cadastro Nacional da Pessoa Jurídica)
docs.text: Brazilian company (legal entity) taxpayer registry number issued by the Federal Revenue Service. Used to identify organizations and companies.

docs.title: Harvest Detection
docs.text: The process of identifying the harvest date or readiness based on vegetation index and crop maturity.

docs.title: Harvest Type
docs.text: Defines the detection mode: INSEASON_HARVEST, HISTORICAL_HARVEST, or HARVEST_READINESS.

docs.title: Threshold Start
docs.text: NDVI value used as a threshold to consider the start of relevant vegetative growth.

docs.title: Average Potential Score
docs.text: Mean of historical potential scores over the last five years.

docs.title: Olympic Mean
docs.text: Mean calculated by excluding the highest value and NaNs, used to reduce the impact of outliers.

docs.title: Standard Deviation
docs.text: Measure of variability in historical potential scores. Higher values indicate greater uncertainty.

docs.title: Risk Score
docs.text: Risk index calculated as: (Standard Deviation / Average) × 100. Indicates the stability of potential over time.

docs.title: Season Break
docs.text: Boolean indicator showing whether a season's score was significantly below the historical average (less than 70% of the Olympic Mean).

docs.title: Emergence Date
docs.text: The date when crop emergence was detected, used as a reference for planted area computation.

docs.title: Processor Mode
docs.text: Defines the computation type: PLANTED_AREA for planted area calculation, CONTROL for unplanted area check.

docs.title: Control Threshold
docs.text: Percentage threshold for unplanted area in CONTROL mode.

docs.title: NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)
docs.text: Calculated as (NIR - Red) / (NIR + Red), NDVI measures vegetation health based on the difference between near-infrared and red light reflectance. Values range from -1 to 1, with higher values indicating healthier, denser vegetation. Application: General vegetation health monitoring, biomass estimation, and crop vigor assessment.

docs.title: EVI (Enhanced Vegetation Index)
docs.text: A modified vegetation index that corrects for atmospheric conditions and canopy background signals. EVI uses blue, red, and near-infrared bands with correction factors to minimize soil and atmospheric influences. Application: Improved sensitivity in high biomass areas, tropical rainforest monitoring, and areas with dense vegetation where NDVI saturates.

docs.title: NDWI (Normalized Difference Water Index)
docs.text: Calculated as (Green - NIR) / (Green + NIR), NDWI measures the water content in vegetation by comparing green and near-infrared reflectance. Higher values indicate higher water content. Application: Water stress detection, irrigation management, and drought monitoring in crops.

docs.title: NDMI (Normalized Difference Moisture Index)
docs.text: Calculated as (NIR - SWIR) / (NIR + SWIR), NDMI uses near-infrared and shortwave infrared bands to assess vegetation water content. Values range from -1 to 1, with higher values indicating higher moisture content. Application: Canopy moisture content monitoring, water stress assessment, and fire risk evaluation.

docs.title: NDRE (Normalized Difference Red Edge)
docs.text: Calculated as (NIR - Red Edge) / (NIR + Red Edge), NDRE uses the red edge band (around 700-750nm) which is sensitive to chlorophyll content. More responsive to plant health variations than NDVI. Application: Nitrogen content assessment, chlorophyll concentration monitoring, and precision agriculture applications for fertilizer management.

docs.title: GNDVI (Green Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)
docs.text: Calculated as (NIR - Green) / (NIR + Green), GNDVI substitutes the green band for the red band in the NDVI formula. More sensitive to chlorophyll concentration variations than NDVI. Application: Chlorophyll content assessment, photosynthetic activity monitoring, and early-stage crop health detection.

docs.title: S2REP (Sentinel-2 Red Edge Position)
docs.text: An index that estimates the position of the red edge inflection point in the spectral reflectance curve using Sentinel-2's red edge bands. The red edge position shifts with changes in chlorophyll content. Application: Chlorophyll and nitrogen status assessment, crop health monitoring, and precision agriculture for variable rate application of nutrients.

docs.title: LAI (Leaf Area Index)
docs.text: A dimensionless measure representing the total one-sided area of leaf tissue per unit ground surface area. LAI quantifies the amount of leaf material in the canopy and is derived from optical remote sensing data. Application: Canopy structure characterization, biomass estimation, crop growth monitoring, and yield prediction models.

docs.title: Biomass Index
docs.text: An index derived from spectral bands to estimate the amount of living plant material (above-ground biomass) in a given area. Various formulations exist using combinations of visible, near-infrared, and shortwave infrared bands. Application: Above-ground biomass estimation, carbon stock assessment, crop productivity monitoring, and yield forecasting.

docs.title: CAB (Chlorophyll A+B)
docs.text: A biophysical variable that estimates the total chlorophyll concentration (Chlorophyll A and B combined) in vegetation canopy. Derived through radiative transfer models or empirical relationships from spectral data. Application: Chlorophyll concentration monitoring, photosynthetic capacity assessment, nitrogen status evaluation, and crop health diagnostics.

docs.title: RVI (Ratio Vegetation Index)
docs.text: Calculated as NIR / Red, RVI is one of the simplest vegetation indices using the ratio between near-infrared and red reflectance. Values typically range from 0 to more than 10 for vegetation. Application: Simple vegetation assessment, quick biomass estimation, and basic crop monitoring where computational simplicity is preferred.

docs.title: Dry Bare Soil Index (DBSI)
docs.text:
The analytic uses the Dry Bare Soil Index calculated medium resolution data. 

DBSI = ((SWIR1 - Green) / (SWIR1 + Green)) - ((NIR - Red) / (NIR + Red))
Formula Components: First Term: (SWIR1 - Green) / (SWIR1 + Green) - Normalized difference using Short-Wave Infrared (SWIR1) and Green bands - Highlights dry soil and bare surfaces - Dry soil exhibits high SWIR reflectance, creating positive values Second Term: (NIR - Red) / (NIR + Red) - This is essentially the NDVI (1) (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) - Measures vegetation greenness and density - Vegetated areas produce high positive values

docs.title: Diagram
docs.text: Several diagrams can be created within your markdown page. To see code related with the example, please click on the view source icon on the top of the page.

docs.title: Flowchart
docs.text:
graph LR
  A[Start] --> B{Error?};
  B -->|Yes| C[Hmm...];
  C --> D[Debug];
  D --> B;
  B ---->|No| E[Yay!];

docs.title: Sequence diagram
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
  autonumber
  Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
  loop Healthcheck
      John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
  end
  Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
  John-->>Alice: Great!
  John->>Bob: How about you?
  Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

docs.title: State diagram
docs.text:
stateDiagram-v2
  state fork_state <<fork>>
    [*] --> fork_state
    fork_state --> State2
    fork_state --> State3

    state join_state <<join>>
    State2 --> join_state
    State3 --> join_state
    join_state --> State4
    State4 --> [*]

docs.title: Class diagram
docs.text:
classDiagram
  Person <|-- Student
  Person <|-- Professor

  Person : +String phoneNumber
  Person : +String emailAddress
  Person: +purchaseParkingPass()

    +int studentNumber
    +int averageMark
    +isEligibleToEnrol()
    +getSeminarsTaken()
  }
  class Professor{
    +int salary
  }
  class Address{
    +String street
    +String city
    +String state
    +int postalCode
    +String country
    -validate()
    +outputAsLabel()

docs.title: 📝 API Reference
docs.text: Browse our comprehensive API documentation across all EarthDaily Agro analytics. Each API provides detailed Swagger documentation with interactive endpoints, request/response examples, and authentication requirements.

docs.title: 📑 Core
docs.text:
• Identity & Authentication

    OAuth 2.0 authentication service for secure API access. Provides token-based authentication with configurable scopes and expiration.

    Swagger Details

  • Entity Management

    Unified store for agricultural master data including fields, seasons, growers, and farm hierarchies. Supports CRUD operations for Ag entities.

    Swagger Details

  • Analytic Store

    Access various analytics derived from imagery and weather data.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 📒 Foundational Analytics
docs.text:
• Field Borders

    Automatic field boundary delineation using deep learning and satellite imagery. Generates accurate field polygons without manual digitization.

    Swagger Details

  • Time Series

    Historical and near-real-time vegetation indices time series. Cloud-masked, smoothed data for accurate temporal analysis of crop development.

    Swagger Details

  • Crop ID

    AI-powered crop type classification using multi-temporal satellite imagery. Identifies major crop types with confidence scores and validation metrics.

    Swagger Details

  • Layer Service

    Access satellite imagery layers, vegetation indices, and derived analytics products. Supports multiple sensors and on-demand processing.

    Swagger Details

  • Vegetation Index Maps

    Generate field-level vegetation index maps including NDVI, EVI, NDRE. Supports prescription mapping and precision agriculture workflows.

    Swagger Details

  • Field Weather

    Historical weather data and forecasts for agricultural fields. Includes temperature, precipitation, humidity, and derived agro-meteorological indices.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: ❗ Benchmark and Warning
docs.text:
• Change Detection

    Detect significant changes in field conditions using multi-temporal satellite analysis. Identifies anomalies, disturbances, and rapid vegetation changes.

    Swagger Details

  • Benchmark

    Compare field performance against historical patterns, regional averages, and peer benchmarks. Supports relative performance analysis.

    Swagger Details

  • In-Season Monitoring

    Real-time crop performance monitoring combining satellite data, weather, and agronomic models. Provides actionable insights for in-season decisions.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 🚩 Risk Management
docs.text:
• Risk Score

    Comprehensive risk assessment combining historical performance, in-season conditions, and predictive analytics. Supports underwriting and portfolio management.

    Historical: Details Swagger In-Season: Details Swagger

  • Environmental Compliance

    Track and report environmental sustainability metrics including carbon sequestration, conservation practices, and regulatory compliance.

    Swagger Details

  • ZARC Agricultural Risk

    Brazilian Agricultural Climate Risk Zoning (ZARC) compliance service. Determines optimal planting windows based on climate risk analysis.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 🌾 Crop Development and Stressors
docs.text:
• Emergence Detection

    Automated detection of crop emergence dates using satellite-based phenology analysis. Monitors planting window and early growth stages.

    Swagger Details

  • Planted Area

    Accurate estimation of planted acreage using crop identification and field boundary analysis. Supports compliance and acreage reporting.

    Swagger Details

  • Greenness

    Monitor crop canopy development and vegetation vigor through growing season. Tracks greenness progression and identifies stress periods.

    Swagger Details

  • Harvest Readiness

    Assess crop maturity and harvest readiness using vegetation indices and phenology models. Optimizes harvest timing decisions.

    Swagger Details

  • Harvest Detection

    Real-time harvest date identification and progress monitoring. Tracks harvest operations across fields and regions using change detection.

    Swagger Details

  • Disease risk

    Evaluate disease risk on location for Corn and Soybeans.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 🌱 Sustainability
docs.text:
• Tillage

    Detect tillage practices and soil disturbance events using radar and optical imagery. Supports conservation agriculture monitoring and carbon programs.

    Swagger Details

  • Cover Crop

    Satellite-based cover crop detection and coverage analysis. Quantifies cover crop presence for sustainability programs.

    Swagger Details

  • Cover Crop Biomass

    Estimate cover crop biomass and carbon sequestration potential. Supports carbon credit programs and soil health initiatives.

    Swagger Details

  • Baresoil

    Estimate the number of days with bare soil exposed.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 🌎 Regional Analytics
docs.text:
• Regional Monitoring

    Large-scale crop monitoring and analytics for regions, counties, and administrative boundaries. Supports portfolio analysis and market intelligence.

    Swagger Details

docs.title: 🎯 Success Cases
docs.text: Below are a few recent examples where EarthDaily data and analysis have led to a much earlier understanding of production concerns and adjustments in forecasted yields by market drivers.

docs.title: 2022 Brazil Soybeans Case Study
docs.text:
Drought in Center-South and Average Yields in Center-North Lead to Lower Production

2022 saw varied results in Brazilian Soybeans depending on where you looked. The Center-North of the country, where the bulk of the crop is grown, received satisfactory precipitation and produced an average crop as shown in our vegetation chart

The Center-South unfortunately experienced the lowest precipitation levels in years starting at the begining of the growing cycle. This lack of rainfall clearly limited the vegetation development to a level below the previously lowest producing year of 2012.

EarthDaily decreased Yield Forecasts in December well before CONAB and USDA reached the same levels near the end of the season. Our clear view of this crop failure in the Center-South allowed our customers to anticipate these eventual drops in production by the USDA and CONAB.

docs.title: 2023 Canadian Durum Wheat Case Study
docs.text:
Early Season Heat and Dryness Shortens the Growing Season

The start of the 2023 Canadian Wheat season started out very similar to the 2021 season. 2021 was a poor year for Canada and this made us adopt a pessimistic position from the beginning. Staring in July, the high temperature and low moisture began to effect NDVI, much like 2021.

Forecasted Yield Starts to Drop Two Months Earlier Than STATCAN

Seeing these trends early allowed us to point out a crop failure well in advance compared to USDA and STATCAN.

docs.title: 2024 Russian Winter Wheat Case Study
docs.text:
Extremely wet start of the cycle

Record dry conditions in the following months

Strong late cold snap in May

Warm waves at the end of the cycle negatively rushing the grain maturation

Weather insights and some analogies with the very poor 2012 crop vigor allowed us to forecast very disappointing winter wheat yields 11 weeks before USDA did!

docs.title: 🌾 Introduction
docs.text:
In volatile agricultural markets, success depends on real-time data. For customers who need more than rumors and anecdata, EarthDaily provides unbiased and consistent data and expertise to understand what’s really happening in all Ag regions.

With 30 years of weather and satellite data, interactive analysis of real-time season developments unable accurate analysis and production estimates.

Feed your proprietary models with best-in-class data, leverage our app to carry out your analyses or work with EarthDaily’s crop analysts for fast access to ready to insights - it’s all possible - find out more below or --contact us--. Continuous satellite monitoring, historical data, and predictive intelligence help you optimize procurement, improve trade strategies, and make confident market decisions.

Multiple delivery channels ensure that EarthDaily Crop Intelligence is available in the format best suited for your business needs.

docs.title: 👥 Target Audience¶
docs.text:
EarthDaily has designed this product for organizations that need timely, accurate, and scalable crop intelligence:

  • Commodity Traders & Analysts Monitor the current vegetation and weather trends in key areas of the world which drive change in the market. Anticipate the market and the changes made by the USDA and other Government Agencies prior to the release of their reports.
  • Food & Beverage Corporates Enhance supply chain transparency, understand import/export constraints from global partners, and improve seasonal planning and procurement.
  • Insurance & Risk Management Firms Accurately assess crop exposure, monitor seasonal progression, and model risk with spatially consistent datasets.
  • Governments & Policy Institutions Support national food security assessments, subsidy programs, and environmental monitoring efforts.

docs.title: 🌾Commodities Intelligence
docs.text:
For customers who need more than rumors and anecdata, EarthDaily provides unbiased and consistent data and expertise to understand what’s really happening in all Ag regions.

With 30 years of weather and satellite data, interactive analysis of real-time season developments unable accurate analysis and production estimates.

Feed your proprietary models with best-in-class data, leverage our app to carry out your analyses or work with EarthDaily’s crop analysts for fast access to ready to insights, it’s all possible - find out more below or contact us.

docs.title: 👥 Target Audience
docs.text:
EarthDaily has designed this product for organizations that need timely, accurate, and scalable crop intelligence:

  • Commodity Traders & Analysts - Monitor the current vegetation and weather trends in key areas of the world which drive change in the market. Anticipate the market and the changes made by the USDA and other Government Agencies prior to the release of their reports.

  • Food & Beverage Corporates - Enhance supply chain transparency, understand import/export constraints from global partners, and improve seasonal planning and procurement.

  • Insurance & Risk Management Firms - Accurately assess crop exposure, monitor seasonal progression, and model risk with spatially consistent datasets.

  • Governments & Policy Institutions - Support national food security assessments, subsidy programs, and environmental monitoring efforts.

docs.title: Weekly Webinars
docs.text:
Join our Crop Analyst for weekly interactive webinars where EarthDaily will review Global Crop Production estimates and the Vegetation and Weather data which are driving these estimates.

Reasons to join our webinars:

  • Insights - Gain valuable insights into crop conditions.
  • Ahead of the market - Stay ahead of the market with information at the beginning of the week which can confirm or challenge the market noise.
  • Production figures - Estimated production of the main grains in the world's main producers.

Webinar recordings are available after they have concluded so you can watch them at a time more convenient for your workflow.

Click here to access a webinar recording

docs.title: Weekly Videos
docs.text:
Weekly short form videos are available to provide updates on the current production conditions and forecasts.

Weekly Videos available include:

  • Global Crop Production Highlights

    • Weekly updates on key production areas where conditions are most different when compared to previous seasons.
    • Watch this video to stay aware of major stories of the growing season.

  • Global crop specific videos for Corn, Soybeans, Wheat, Rapeseed/Canola, and Barley

    • Weekly updates on all the production areas of the target crop
    • Highlights when our forecasts or conditions have changed recently or we differ from USDA

docs.title: All Crops Global Report
docs.text:
Our Weekly Global Report is a detailed, comprehensive view showcasing all you would want to know about the production conditions of Corn, Soybeans, Wheat, Rapeseed/Canola, and Barley in the top 10 growing regions of the world (USA, Canada, Brazil, Argentina, Australia, Europe, Russia, Ukraine, India, and China).

The Weekly Global Report includes Forecasted Yield and Production values as well as the current vegetation, weather, and production maps and charts which are driving Forecasted Yields.

docs.title: 🗺️ Crop Mask API (STAC) Documentation
docs.text:
The Crop Mask API provides access to public and private crop mask layers. These datasets can be used for agricultural monitoring, land classification, and crop analytics.

The API is built on top of the EarthDaily platform and follows the STAC (SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog) standard.

docs.title: 🔐 Authentication
docs.text:
• Endpoint: POST https://api.earthdaily.com/account_management/v1/authentication/api_tokens/exchange

  • Request Body: JSON containing your EDS_CLIENT_ID and EDS_SECRET.

  • Response: JSON object with an access_token, used in subsequent requests via: 

    Authorization: Bearer <access_token>

docs.title: 📚 Collections
docs.text:
• Public Crop Mask → public-crop-mask

    The following crop mask layers are referenced on the STAC Catalog from Earthdaily Data Store - Cropland Data Layer (CDL), a product from United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS). The CDL is an annual raster, geo-referenced, crop-specific land cover data layer produced using satellite imagery and extensive agricultural ground reference data. For more information, visit the Cropland Data Layer homepage.

    • Registre Parcellaire Graphique (RPG), a product from the French Ministry of Agriculture and Food Sovereignty. The RPG is an annual, vector-based, geo-referenced dataset that describes the agricultural parcels declared by farmers in the context of the European Union’s Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). It provides detailed crop type information at the parcel level. For more information, visit the RPG portal.

    • Crop Type Map (CTM), a product provided by the German Aerospace Center (DLR). The CTM is a raster, geo-referenced dataset generated from satellite imagery (such as Sentinel-2) using advanced classification algorithms. It provides annual information on crop type distribution at field level. For more information, visit the DLR website.

All layers are referenced in one place for convenience, enabling seamless analysis of historical trends, crop rotations, and year-over-year changes — without the need to manage multiple data sources.

  • Private Crop Mask (EDAgro Analytics) → edagro-analytics-crops-layer

The private collection contains crop mask layers computed during the growing season, enabling enabling data-driven decisions based on crop-specific analytics.

docs.title: 🔍 Search for Crop Mask Items
docs.text:
Endpoint: GET https://api.earthdaily.com/platform/v1/stac/search

Parameters: - collections → The collection ID (e.g., edagro-analytics-crops-layer) - bbox → Bounding box filter [minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat] - datetime → Date or date range (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM-DD/YYYY-MM-DD) - limit → Maximum number of results

Response Example:

{
  "type": "FeatureCollection",
  "features": [
    {
      "id": "edagro_cropmask_france_2023",
      "collection": "edagro-analytics-crops-layer",
      "bbox": [2.0, 43.0, 3.0, 44.0],
      "properties": {
        "datetime": "2023-07-01T00:00:00Z",
        "crop_type": "maize",
        "confidence": 0.92
      },
      "assets": {
        "mask": {
          "href": "https://api.earthdaily.com/assets/edagro-analytics-crops-layer/edagro_cropmask_france_2023.tif",
          "type": "image/tiff",
          "title": "Crop Mask for Maize - France, 2023"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: 💼 Downloading a Crop Mask
docs.text:
1. Perform a search on the edagro-analytics-crops-layer collection.
  2. From the response, identify the assets section.

  3. Use the href URL to download the file.

  4. Request: A standard GET request to the href URL, with your access token if required.

  5. Response: A binary GeoTIFF file that can be opened in GIS software or processed with remote sensing libraries.

docs.title: 🛠 Error Handling
docs.text: Status Code Meaning 401 Unauthorized – check your token 403 Forbidden – insufficient access 404 Collection or item not found 429 Too many requests – rate limited 500 Internal server error

docs.title: ⚙️ Best Practices
docs.text:
• Apply filters (bbox, datetime) to reduce query size.
  • Cache authentication tokens until expiry.
  • Request access to edagro-analytics-crops-layer to access any dataset.

docs.title: Field-Level API to get Crop Rotations
🌾 Introduction
docs.text: The Field-Level Crop Mask API enables querying the planted crops for a given geometry and time window. The information is retrieved from the crop masks produced internally or sourced from public data. Understanding which crop has been planted is a foundational step for many downstream services.

docs.title: Access via REST API
docs.text:
The Field-Level Crop Mask API encompasses a suite of four endpoints designed to support variable applications and to be easily integrated into internal systems, analytical pipelines, or external applications.

Method Route Description Request Post /cropmasks/crops Retrieve which crops are presen within a geometry for one or several agricultural seasons leveraging the latest crop mask available JSON body with list of parameters Post /cropmasks/crop-details Retrieve which crops are detected within a geometry and for all the crop masks available for one or more agricultural seasons JSON body with list of parameters Post /cropmasks/years Return the year(s) in which a specific crop has been detected within a given geometry, based on crop mask data. JSON body with list of parameters Post /cropmasks/layers-crop Retrieve which fields have a specific crop within a defined area for a targeted agricultural season

docs.title: Supported Geometries
docs.text: The Field-Level Crop Mask API supports Polygon geometries (fields level) in WKT format & Coordinates must be provided in WGS 84 (EPSG:4326)

docs.title: 🔐 Authentication
docs.text:
All endpoints require secure access via Identity Server API, which manages:

  • User and application-level authentication
  • Token-based access (OAuth 2.0)
  • Permission scopes to control access to specific data layers or regions

docs.title: 🌱 Endpoint 1: Dominant Crop Detection
docs.text: /cropmasks/crops (POST)

docs.title: 🧾 Purpose
docs.text: Identify the dominant crop(s) within a given geometry for one or more years by querying internal and external crop mask sources. This endpoint returns a list of detected crops, their properties, and the coverage percentage within the input field.

docs.title: ⚙️ High-Level Functionality
docs.text:
• The user submits a geometry in WKT format.
  • Optional metadata fields can be specified through Properties and CropProperties.
  • Filters can be applied based on year, source, product type, season, and minimum coverage percentage.
  • The response lists the detected crops with associated attributes, sorted by dominance if specified.

docs.title: 📌 Business Rules
docs.text:
• GeometryWkt is mandatory.
  • If CropProperties is defined, you must explicitly list each desired property.
  • The following fields are returned by default (unless their values are null), even if not listed in the request:
  • CropName
  • EDACropCode
  • RawCropName
  • CropMaskPercent

docs.title: 🧾 Purpose
docs.text: Retrieve all crop occurrences detected within a given geometry, using every available crop mask. This endpoint returns detailed crop detection results year by year, for each mask used.

docs.title: ⚙️ High-Level Functionality
docs.text:
• Accepts the same input structure as /cropmasks/crops.
  • For each year in the defined range, returns crop detections from all masks (not just the dominant one).
  • Aggregates results per year and per mask, providing both crop-specific and mask-specific properties.

docs.title: 📌 Business Rules
docs.text:
• GeometryWkt is mandatory.
  • If CropProperties is defined, you must explicitly list each desired property.
  • The following fields are returned by default (unless their values are null), even if not listed in the request:
  • CropName
  • EDACropCode
  • RawCropName

docs.title: 🧾 Purpose
docs.text: Return the year(s) in which a specific crop has been detected within a given geometry, based on crop mask data. This is useful for historical crop presence analysis and crop rotation tracking.

docs.title: ⚙️ High-Level Functionality
docs.text:
• The user provides a geometry and optionally filters for a specific crop using one or more crop attributes.
  • The system checks all relevant crop masks to determine in which years the crop is present.
  • Optional filters let the user refine results by collections, products, sources, crop dominance, and percentage threshold.

docs.title: 📌 Business Rules
docs.text:
• GeometryWkt is mandatory.
  • At least one crop attribute in CropInfo must be provided to identify the target crop.
  • If CropMaskPercentMin is set, years in which the crop coverage is below the specified threshold will not be returned.
  • If TakeOnlyMajorityCrop is true, only the main (most dominant) crop will be considered for each year.

docs.title: 🌱 Endpoint 4: /cropmasks/layers-crop (POST)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Retrieve which fields have a specific crop within a defined area for a targeted agricultural season.
  • Output: Array listing the intersected items where the given crop has been detected for a given year.
  • Get more details: Reach out your local contact to get more details on how to use this endpoint.

docs.title: 🧰 Developer Resources
docs.text:
Interactive API documentation is available via Swagger:

👉 CropMask API Swagger (PROD)

You can use this interface to:

  • Explore available endpoints

docs.title: Available Across Brazil’s Major Agricultural Zones: in-season satellite-based crop classification.
docs.text:
EarthDaily Crop Identification product delivers accurate, in-season crop classification at national scale, covering Brazil’s agricultural regions. From Mato Grosso to Paraná, and spanning both Safra and Safrinha cycles, the product provides near real-time visibility into what’s growing—supporting critical decisions in one of the world’s largest and most dynamic agricultural economies.

Covered crops include: - Safra Season: Soybean, First Corn, Sugarcane, Cotton, and Rice - Safrinha Season: Second Corn, Sugarcane, Cotton, and Winter Wheat

Additional crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap.

docs.title: ⌛ In-Season Deliveries
docs.text:
To support timely decisions throughout the growing season, crop classification layers are delivered in two stages per cropping cycle. This phased approach provides progressively refined insights as new satellite and weather data become available.

Delivery schedule: - Safra Season: Early March and Early June - Safrinha Season: Early June and Early August

Each delivery reflects the most recent satellite imagery and model outputs, ensuring increasing accuracy as the season progresses.

docs.title: 🎯 Model Performance
docs.text:
Our AI models deliver high accuracy for major row crops. Below are the typical F1 score ranges achieved under operational conditions:

  • Soybean: > 0.95
  • 1st Corn (Safra): 0.85 – 0.90
  • 2nd Corn (Safrinha): 0.90 – 0.95
  • Sugarcane: 0.80 – 0.85
  • Rice: 0.85 – 0.90
  • Cotton: 0.60 – 0.70
  • Wheat: 0.85 – 0.90

docs.title: 📅 Historical Layers
docs.text: Historical crop classification layers are available starting from 2019. These datasets support model training, historical crop rotation analysis, and robust year-over-year comparisons—enabling more informed long-term planning.

docs.title: 🔧 Flexible Delivery Options
docs.text:
Our Crop Identification product is designed for seamless integration into your existing systems, with two delivery options via API:

  • Crop Mask API (STAC): Access spatially indexed, pre-processed crop maps in standard geospatial formats such as GeoTIFF—ideal for large-area analysis.
  • Field-Level API: Retrieve crop type predictions linked to known field boundaries for precision use at the farm or parcel level.

Both options are scalable, reliable, and built to fit directly into your data pipeline. Explore full technical specifications in our API Documentation.

docs.title: ❓ FAQ
docs.text:
• What crops are covered in EarthDaily’s Brazil crop identification product? Soybean, Corn (Safra and Safrinha), Sugarcane, Cotton, Wheat, and Rice.

  • How accurate is the model? F1 scores range from 0.60 (cotton) to >0.95 (soybean), based on validated in-season performance.

  • How often is the data updated? Twice per cropping season, with progressive refinement as more satellite imagery is collected.

  • Can I access data for past seasons? Yes, historical data is available from 2019 onward.

  • What regions of Brazil are supported? Key agricultural zones including Mato Grosso, Paraná, Goiás, Bahia, and others.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: 🌍 Available Across France, UK & Germany
docs.text:
The EarthDaily Crop Identification product is fully operational across France, UK and Germany, providing in-season crop classification at national scale. From the Beauce plains to Bavaria, the solution delivers timely, consistent, and high-resolution insights into crop distribution—supporting decision-making in three of Europe’s largest and most diverse agricultural producers.

Covered crops are as follows:

France UK Germany Winter Wheat Winter Wheat Winter Wheat Spring Barley Spring Barley Spring Barley Winter Barley Winter Barley Winter Barley Rapeseed Rapeseed Rapeseed Corn Corn Sugar Beet Sugar Beet Sunflower

Additional crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap.

docs.title: ⌛ In-Season Deliveries
docs.text:
Crop Identification layers are updated progressively throughout the growing season, enabling early and reliable identification of crop types. It is designed for in‑season decision making, not just post‑harvest analysis.

Delivery schedule:

  • March 21st – Winter crops development​
  • July 7th – Spring crops development & Winter crops update​
  • Sept 7th – End of Season evaluation

Additional delivery dates can be added upon request. These in-season deliveries enable monitoring of planted areas, detection of acreage variations, and dynamic adjustment of supply and production forecasts.

docs.title: 🎯 Model Performance
docs.text:
Our AI models deliver high accuracy across major crops in both France and Germany. Typical F1 score ranges under operational conditions are:

France UK Germany Winter Wheat: 0.71-0.92 Winter Wheat: 0.76-0.90 Winter Wheat: 0.75-0.80 Spring Barley: 0.78-0.81 Spring Barley: 0.76 Spring Barley: 0.56 Winter Barley: 0.66-0.9 Winter Barley: 0.69-0.86 Winter Barley: 0.88 Rapeseed: 0.9-0.97 Rapeseed: 0.86-0.93 Rapeseed: 0.97 Corn: 0.85-0.95 Corn: 0.91 Sugar Beet: 0.81-0.94 Sugar Beet: 0.85 Sunflower: 0.62-0.88

docs.title: 📅 Historical Layers
docs.text: To support long-term analysis, we provide historical crop classification layers starting from 2019, leveraging public EU datasets. Centralizing all layers simplifies the analysis of crop rotations, land-use patterns, and annual changes, creating reliable historical coverage where none is available.

docs.title: 🔧 Flexible Delivery Options
docs.text:
Our product is designed for easy integration into your workflows, with two API-based delivery mechanisms:

  • Crop Mask API (STAC): Access spatially indexed, pre-processed crop maps in standard geospatial formats (GeoTIFF). Ideal for national or regional-scale analysis.
  • Field-Level API: Retrieve crop type predictions linked to known field boundaries for precision use cases at parcel level.

Both options are scalable, reliable, and built to fit directly into your data pipeline. Explore full technical specifications in our API Documentation.

docs.title: ❓ FAQ
docs.text:
What crops are covered in EarthDaily’s France, UK & Germany crop identification product?

  • France: Winter Wheat, Spring Barley, Winter Barley, Rapeseed, Corn, Sunflower, Sugar Beet
  • UK: Winter Wheat, Spring Barley, Winter Barley, Rapeseed
  • Germany: Winter Wheat, Spring Barley, Winter Barley, Rapeseed, Corn, Sugar Beet

How accurate is the model?

F1 scores range from 0.56 (Spring Barley) to >0.97 (Rapeseed), validated under in-season conditions.

How often is the data updated?

3 deliveries are scheduled during the 2026 season: March 21st, July 7th, and September 7th.

Can I access data for past seasons?

Yes, historical layers are available from 2019 onward.

What regions are supported?

The coverage spans the entire territories of France, UK and Germany.

docs.title: Product Overview - Scalable Crop Classification from Space
🗺️ Get Real-time Crop Classification at Scale
docs.text:
Traditionally, accurate and timely crop mapping has come at a high cost. Field surveys, farmer reports, and manual sampling methods provide precise data—but they are time-consuming, expensive to scale, and often lag behind the pace of market or agro-climatic events. By the time insights reach decision-makers, key opportunities may already be missed—or decisions are made without a full picture of what’s happening in the field. Today, that model is changing.

EarthDaily's Crop Classification product combines satellite imagery, weather data, and advanced AI models to accurately detect what crops are planted and where—all during the active growing season, at national scale.

This breakthrough enables a new standard of crop intelligence that is:

  • Timely available – Crop masks are provided during the growing season, not months after harvest
  • Scalable – Covering millions of hectares with consistent accuracy
  • Cost-efficient – Eliminating the need for large-scale field surveys
  • Seamless – Accessible through APIs and ready for integration into your business workflows

Whether you are forecasting crop supply, managing agricultural risk, or optimizing procurement strategies, our solution brings unprecedented scale and efficiency to understanding what’s growing—across regions or entire countries.

docs.title: 👥 Target Audience
docs.text:
EarthDaily has designed this product for organizations that need timely, accurate, and scalable agricultural intelligence—and have the technical capacity to integrate data via APIs:

  • AgTech Companies & Platforms Power digital farming tools, agronomic models, and targeted crop-specific advice for mid-season decisions.

  • Commodity Traders & Analysts Improve crop acreage estimation, optimize sourcing strategies, and gain early signals of supply shifts for major crops.

  • Food & Beverage Corporates Enhance supply chain transparency, support ESG commitments, and improve seasonal planning and procurement.

  • Insurance & Risk Management Firms Accurately assess crop exposure, monitor planting declarations, and model risk with spatially consistent datasets.

  • Governments & Policy Institutions Support national food security assessments, subsidy programs, and environmental monitoring efforts.

docs.title: 🌎 Geographic Coverage and Crops
docs.text:
Crop Identification is currently available for the United States and Brazil, covering key agricultural regions and focusing on the main row crops grown in each country.

Crop mask layers are generated and updated during the active growing season, providing near-real-time visibility into crop distribution as the season progresses.

Coverage includes crops such as:

  • USA: Corn, Soybean, Wheat, Cotton
  • Brazil: Soybean, Corn (first and second seasons), Sugarcane, Cotton, Wheat and Rice
  • France: Winter wheat, Barley, Oil Seed Rape, Corn, Sunflower and Sugarbeet
  • Germany: Winter wheat, Barley, Oil Seed Rape, Corn and Sugarbeet

Additional countries and crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap. Contact us to learn more.

docs.title: 🔧 Flexible Delivery to Fit Your Workflow
docs.text:
Crop Identification is designed for seamless integration into your operations, offering two delivery mechanisms to match your needs:

  • API Access to Crop Mask Layers (via STAC Catalog) Query spatially and temporally indexed crop masks through our API, fully referenced in a SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog (STAC). Ideal for applications that require pre-processed crop masks over large areas in standard geospatial formats (e.g., GeoTIFF).

  • API Access to Field-Level Information Retrieve crop type predictions linked to individual field boundaries, enabling precise, field-level intelligence. Suitable for systems that work with known field geometries (Automated field boundaries are also available)

No matter your architecture or scale, our flexible delivery options make it easy to bring timely, accurate crop intelligence into your existing workflows.

Explore further details in our API Documentation.

docs.title: ❓ FAQ
docs.text:
What is satellite crop identification?

We use optical and SAR satellite data to detect which crop is growing on every plot of land.

How accurate is EarthDaily’s crop classification?

Soybean in Brazil: F1-score > 0.95 Corn in the USA Corn Belt: F1-score > 0.95 Discover more in the dedicated Countries pages.

Can I access crop data during the season?

Yes, we deliver crop classification data 6 to 12 months before local agencies.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: 🌎 Available Across the United States
docs.text:
The EarthDaily Crop Identification product is fully operational across the entire U.S., providing in-season crop classification at national scale. From the Corn Belt to the Mississippi Delta and the Great Plains, it delivers timely, consistent, and high-resolution insights into crop distribution—supporting critical decisions in one of the world’s largest agricultural producers.

Coverage includes key row crops such as Corn, Soybean, Winter Wheat, Spring Wheat, and Cotton.

Additional crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap.

docs.title: 📤 In-Season Deliveries
docs.text:
Crop classification layers are delivered during the growing season, with progressive updates that incorporate the latest satellite imagery and weather-adjusted model outputs.

Delivery schedule:

  • Mid-June
  • Mid-July

Additional delivery dates can be added upon request. This cadence enables organizations to track acreage distribution and refine supply outlooks as the season advances.

docs.title: 🎯 Model Performance
docs.text:
Our AI models deliver high accuracy for major U.S. row crops. Below are the typical F1 score ranges achieved under operational conditions:

  • Corn: 0.85 – 0.90
  • Soybean: 0.85 – 0.90
  • Winter Wheat: 0.75 – 0.80
  • Spring Wheat: 0.75 – 0.80
  • Cotton: 0.70 – 0.75

docs.title: 🗺️ Historical Layers
docs.text: To support long-term analysis, we provide historical crop classification layers starting from 2008 using public USDA datasets. All layers are referenced in one place for convenience, enabling seamless analysis of historical trends, crop rotations, and year-over-year changes — without the need to manage multiple data sources.

docs.title: 🔧 Flexible Delivery Options
docs.text:
The product is designed for seamless integration into your workflows, with two API-based delivery mechanisms:

  • Crop Mask API (STAC): Access spatially indexed, pre-processed crop maps in standard geospatial formats such as GeoTIFF—ideal for large-area analysis.
  • Field-Level API: Retrieve crop type predictions linked to known field boundaries for precision use at the farm or parcel level.

Both options are scalable, reliable, and built to fit directly into your data pipeline.

Explore full technical specifications in our API Documentation.

docs.title: ❓ FAQ
docs.text:
What crops are covered in EarthDaily’s U.S. Crop Identification product?

Corn, Soybean, Winter Wheat, Spring Wheat, and Cotton.

How accurate is the model?

F1 scores range from 0.70 (Cotton) to >0.85 (Corn, Soybean), based on validated in-season performance.

How often is the data updated?

Twice per cropping season, with progressive refinement as more satellite imagery is collected.

Can I access data for past seasons?

Yes, historical data is available from 2008 onward.

What regions of the U.S. are supported?

Coverage spans the entire country.

What if I only need data for specific areas?

You can request access to selected states as needed.

docs.title: Product Overview - Scalable Crop Classification from Space
🗺️ Get real-time crop classification and mapping at national scale using satellite imagery, weather data, and AI.
Introduction
docs.text:
Traditionally, accurate and timely crop mapping has come at a high cost. Field surveys, farmer reports, and manual sampling methods provide precise data—but they are time-consuming, expensive to scale, and often lag behind the pace of market or agro-climatic events. By the time insights reach decision-makers, key opportunities may already be missed—or decisions are made without a full picture of what’s happening in the field. Today, that model is changing.

EarthDaily's Crop Classification product combines satellite imagery, weather data, and advanced AI models to accurately detect what crops are planted and where—all during the active growing season, at national scale.

This breakthrough enables a new standard of crop intelligence that is: - Timely available – Crop masks are provided during the growing season, not months after harvest - Scalable – Covering millions of hectares with consistent accuracy - Cost-efficient – Eliminating the need for large-scale field surveys - Seamless – Accessible through APIs and ready for integration into your business workflows

Whether you are forecasting crop supply, managing agricultural risk, or optimizing procurement strategies, our solution brings unprecedented scale and efficiency to understanding what’s growing—across regions or entire countries.

docs.title: 👥 Target Audience
docs.text:
EarthDaily has designed this product for organizations that need timely, accurate, and scalable agricultural intelligence—and have the technical capacity to integrate data via APIs:

  • AgTech Companies & Platforms Power digital farming tools, agronomic models, and targeted crop-specific advice for mid-season decisions.

  • Commodity Traders & Analysts Improve crop acreage estimation, optimize sourcing strategies, and gain early signals of supply shifts for major crops.

  • Food & Beverage Corporates Enhance supply chain transparency, support ESG commitments, and improve seasonal planning and procurement.

  • Insurance & Risk Management Firms Accurately assess crop exposure, monitor planting declarations, and model risk with spatially consistent datasets.

  • Governments & Policy Institutions Support national food security assessments, subsidy programs, and environmental monitoring efforts.

docs.title: 🌎 Geographic Coverage and Crops
docs.text:
Crop Identification is currently available for the United States and Brazil, covering key agricultural regions and focusing on the main row crops grown in each country.

Crop mask layers are generated and updated during the active growing season, providing near-real-time visibility into crop distribution as the season progresses.

Coverage includes crops such as: - USA: Corn, Soybean, Wheat, Cotton - Brazil: Soybean, Corn (first and second seasons), Sugarcane, Cotton, Wheat and Rice

Additional countries and crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap. Contact us here to know more.

docs.title: 🔧 Flexible Delivery to Fit Your Workflow
docs.text:
Crop Identification is designed for seamless integration into your operations, offering two delivery mechanisms to match your needs:

  • API Access to Crop Mask Layers (via STAC Catalog) Query spatially and temporally indexed crop masks through our API, fully referenced in a SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog (STAC). Ideal for applications that require pre-processed crop masks over large areas in standard geospatial formats (e.g., GeoTIFF).

  • API Access to Field-Level Information Retrieve crop type predictions linked to individual field boundaries, enabling precise, field-level intelligence. Suitable for systems that work with known field geometries. (Automated field boundaries is also available)

No matter your architecture or scale, our flexible delivery options make it easy to bring timely, accurate crop intelligence into your existing workflows.

Explore further details in our API Documentation

docs.title: ❓ FAQ
docs.text:
• What is satellite crop identification? We use optical and SAR satellite data to detect which crop is growing on every plot of land.

  • How accurate is EarthDaily’s crop classification? Soybean in Brazil: F1-score > 0.95 Corn in the USA Corn Belt: F1-score > 0.95 Discover more in the dedicated Countries pages.

  • Can I access crop data during the season? Yes, we deliver crop classification data 6 to 12 months before local agencies.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: Available across France & Germany
docs.text:
The EarthDaily Crop Identification product is fully operational across both France and Germany, providing in-season crop classification at national scale. From the Beauce plains to Bavaria, the solution delivers timely, consistent, and high-resolution insights into crop distribution—supporting decision-making in two of Europe’s largest and most diverse agricultural producers.

Covered crops are as follows:

France Germany Winter Wheat Winter Wheat Barley Barley Oil Seed Rape Oil Seed Rape Corn Corn Sunflower Sugar Beet Sugar Beet

Additional crops can be supported upon request or as part of our product roadmap.

docs.title: In-Season Deliveries
docs.text:
Crop classification layers are delivered during the growing season, providing a good evaluation of winter crops and an early assessment of spring crops.

Delivery schedule: - Mid-June

Additional delivery dates can be added upon request. These in-season deliveries enable monitoring of planted areas, detection of acreage variations, and dynamic adjustment of supply and production forecasts.

docs.title: Model Performance
docs.text:
Our AI models deliver high accuracy across major crops in both France and Germany. Typical F1 score ranges under operational conditions are:

France Germany Winter Wheat: 0.85-0.90 Winter Wheat: 0.75-0.80 Barley: 0.85-0.90 Barley: 0.70-0.75 Oil Seed Rape: >0.95 Oil Seed Rape: 0.90-0.95 Corn: 0.80-0.85 Corn: 0.60-0.65 Sunflower: 0.45-0.50 Sugar Beet: 0.70-0.75

Note: Spring crop detection such as sunflower is limited due to the earliness of the prediction.

docs.title: 🌱 Detection of Key Phenological Stages
docs.text:
Our phenology processors reliably detect key crop events, giving you a clear picture of each field’s progression through the season and how it compares to historical patterns:

  • Emergence detection (historical, in-season, delay)
  • Greenness readiness for peak-season assessments
  • Corn silking date (calibrated for Europe)
  • Harvest readiness
  • Harvest detection (historical & in-season)

These insights eliminate guesswork, optimize scouting, and enable better planning across your entire portfolio.

docs.title: 🔍 Spatial Change Detection
docs.text:
Your fields are constantly changing across the growing season, and some shifts can be easy to miss. The Digital Ag Solution enables you to monitor these dynamics in near real time, helping you quickly identify fields with significant changes and prioritize where to visit first.

The Change Detection analytic highlights where conditions within a field are shifting—revealing early weak zones, emerging stress, and how in-field variability develops over time. This spatial insight allows you to detect issues sooner, understand their progression, and target interventions with greater precision.

Learn more about Change Detection here.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: 🚜 Turning Insights into Action
docs.text:
Turn insights into action with Satellite-Derived Management Zones (SAMZ) that help you understand field variability over time and under different weather conditions, guiding targeted operations. When it is time to execute, generate Rx Maps that support precise input application, optimizing both cost and performance. Whether you’re planting, fertilizing, or applying any number of products, we support your applications with zoning precision and the ability to choose product quantities based on composition and unit selection.

Identify emerging issues at a glance with our HotSpot Processor, which highlights areas that are changing and may require immediate attention—ensuring you never miss a developing problem and can act fast.

docs.title: 📌 Custom Insights for Your Precise Need
docs.text:
With 35 years of experience, we’ve learned a great deal from our customers. Through that learning, we’ve developed specific analytics, reports, and exports tailored to their business needs—adding value for their operations and their customers alike. Some of these include:

  • Harvest Date Prediction processor, facilitating the timing of your harvest operations
  • PDF Reports with your logos and branding, telling a clear story you can easily distribute
  • Exports in Shapefiles or CSVs of your requested datasets
  • John Deere DataSync — seamlessly send maps to the John Deere Information System
  • Notifications configured to your preferences, adjustable anytime
  • Email campaigns with vital, up-to-date information and insights

docs.title: 🗺️Introduction
docs.text:
Agriculture is evolving, and growers now expect co-ops, input retailers, and service providers to deliver more than inputs — they are looking for holistic, data-driven support that helps them navigate agronomic, environmental, and economic challenges. Meeting these expectations requires deeper, more consistent insight into field performance than traditional scouting or experience alone can provide.

At the same time, agronomists and advisors are responsible for supervising larger and more complex grower portfolios than ever before, making it increasingly difficult to provide precise, field-adjusted recommendations for every field of a farm. Distinguishing a field that is trending positively from one that is quietly declining is subtle, yet critical — and often impossible to assess without objective, standardized data.

The Digital Ag solution addresses this need by delivering a clear, up-to-date view of every field in your portfolio. Through harmonized indicators, trend monitoring, and anomaly detection, it equips advisors with the evidence they need to guide growers with confidence, justify input adjustments, and intervene proactively when conditions begin to shift.

The Digital Ag solution also serves as a foundational data layer for advanced analytics for Data Science Team. Its standardized, high-quality datasets feed seamlessly into modeling pipelines — enabling teams to build predictive tools, refine algorithms, and power the next generation of digital agriculture solutions.

docs.title: 👥 Target Audience
docs.text:
The Digital Ag solution provides instant field-wide visibility across your entire portfolio — so you know exactly where to focus before problems become losses. With real-time crop condition insights, anomaly detection, and trend tracking, you can back your agronomic guidance with objective data. You retain full control of the “last mile,” reinforcing your role as a trusted advisor.

  • Agronomists & Field Advisors The Digital Ag analytics engine delivers AI-ready, standardized datasets out of the box. Instead of spending your time on preprocessing, you receive curated agronomic indicators, crop conditions, and field-level metrics that feed directly into your modeling pipeline—accelerating experimentation, improving model accuracy, and reducing iteration cycles. EarthDaily has designed this product for organizations that need timely, accurate, and scalable agricultural intelligence—and have the technical capacity to integrate data via APIs:

  • AgTech Companies & Platforms Power digital farming tools, agronomic models, and targeted crop-specific advice for mid-season decisions.

docs.title: 📋 Capabilities
docs.text:
1. Field Boundaries & Crop Identification. Accurate, up-to-date field boundaries and crop ID layers provide the foundation for consistent field-level analytics across large territories.

  2. Field-Level Maps & Time Series. Harmonized vegetation, biomass, and crop-condition indicators are available as both maps and time series. This allows users to monitor crop conditions, track seasonal development, and understand historical trends.

  3. Crop Events & Change Detection. Automated detection of key agronomic events—such as emergence, peak growth, and senescence—helps users track crop development with precision. Change-detection analytics highlight sudden or unexpected shifts in field behavior, supporting faster diagnosis of issues like stress, disease, or operational anomalies.

  4. Field Benchmarking. Benchmarking tools compare each field against its own historical performance, similar fields in the portfolio, or regional trends. This contextual insight helps advisors assess whether a field is performing as expected, flag outliers, and prioritize interventions based on relative performance.

  5. Decision-Support Tools. Decision-support capabilities include generating management zones and prescription (Rx) maps for variable-rate input applications, as well as hotspot detection for guided scouting.

docs.title: 🌎 Geographic Coverage and Crops
docs.text:
The Digital Ag Solution leverages both public and private satellite constellations to ensure reliable, scalable coverage across agricultural regions worldwide.

Our primary focus is on major raw crops such as cereals, oilseeds, and sugar crops, where consistent, field-level intelligence is essential for operational and modeling workflows.

What sets us apart is our advanced, agriculture-specific cloud-masking technology, applied in targeted operational regions to ensure clean, reliable inputs for downstream analytics.

In addition, all data sources are fully cross-calibrated to guarantee the spatial and temporal consistency of our analytics. Scalable processing, seamless integration, and consistent quality controls have been part of our business for more than 35 years.

docs.title: 🎯 Analyzing Field Productivity (Year-over-Year Trends)
docs.text:
See the big picture. Spot long-term shifts. Protect future yield.

Every season tells a story—yet without a consistent historical record, it is difficult to know whether a field is improving, declining, or deviating from its normal trajectory.

The Digital Ag solution enables you to track field performance against its own historical patterns using two key analytics: Potential Score and Risk Score.

docs.title: Potential Score (Historical & In-Season)
docs.text:
This analytic evaluates how a field performs during the growing season compared to its historical performance for the same crop. Using satellite imagery time series, it provides a simple, scalable indicator leveraging vegetation development as a proxy for yield potential. With minimal inputs required, the Potential Score offers a consistent, repeatable way to benchmark field productivity across large portfolios.

Learn more about Historical Potential Score here.

Learn more about In-Season Potential Score here.

docs.title: Risk Score
docs.text:
The Risk Score measures how stable or variable a field’s performance has been over time by analyzing fluctuations in its historical Potential Scores. It highlights underlying production risks that may not be visible in a single season.

  • Score of 20 → reflects stable, consistent yields
  • Score of 65 → indicates significant variability and higher production risk

These temporal benchmarks reveal anomalies, surface risks, and help identify management opportunities during the growing season.

docs.title: 📈 Field Benchmarking Makes Comparison Easy
docs.text: The Digital Ag Solution helps you understand whether a field is behaving as expected by benchmarking it against neighboring fields under similar growing conditions. By comparing vegetation development across nearby fields, you can quickly identify growth anomalies, distinguish field-specific issues from regional trends, and prioritize where deeper investigation or intervention is needed.

docs.title: 📋 Field Ranking
docs.text:
The Field Ranking analytic compares the growth development of a defined set of fields, making it easy to identify top-performing fields and highlight those falling behind. By ordering fields based on their vegetation vigor, advisors can quickly see which fields require immediate attention and which are tracking as expected.

A complete, season-long intelligence layer that transforms how you monitor crop growth, compare field performance, and detect agronomic change. You will manage fields with more confidence than ever before.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: 📚 Establish Boundaries and Crop History for Your Fields
docs.text:
We make it easy for you to onboard your operation by creating Grower, Farm, and Field entities using multiple means – automated field creation, using a field boundary selection layer (in some regions), or uploading your existing field boundaries into our tools. Then, we start the computation of analytics immediately.

You can update your farm and field entities anytime! With different cropping cycles, land sales and rent, or changes to your farm operation, we have made it quick and easy to make updates and continue the insights for each crop and every season.

Learn more about Automated Field Boundaries here.

docs.title: 🌾 Crop Identification & Rotation Intelligence
docs.text: To help quickly understand a farm's context, the Digital Ag Solution can automatically retrieve crop rotation history using our Crop Identification layers. During the active growing season, it can also confirm the planted crop, providing clarity on current cropping patterns and supporting a clearer understanding of territory-wide dynamics.

docs.title: Field Level Time Series, Maps, and Weather
🧭 Visualize Your Field from Every Angle
docs.text:
Monitoring crop vigor and diagnosing stress early is essential for preventing yield losses. The Digital Ag solution provides a complete suite of vegetation indices and biophysical variables designed to surface issues quickly and clearly:

  • Track canopy development with indices such as NDVI, EVI, and GNDVI, or go deeper with biophysical variables such as LAI and Biomass, which serve as strong proxies for yield potential and overall crop productivity.
  • Adjust nitrogen nutrition with indices like S2REP or NDRE, which are linked to chlorophyll content and act as reliable indicators of nitrogen uptake.
  • Detect water stress with NDMI, helping you identify moisture limitations.
  • Evaluate light-use efficiency and canopy function with FAPAR and FCover, which provide deeper insight into crop photosynthetic activity and the fraction of ground effectively covered by vegetation.

docs.title: 📖 Time Series Captures Your Field’s Track Record
docs.text:
Stay ahead of crop development and yield risks with continuous, season-long visibility into field performance. The Digital Ag Solution provides one of the industry’s most comprehensive temporal datasets—helping you understand not only what is happening today, but how each field has evolved over time.

With our medium-resolution imagery time series—built on Sentinel-2, Landsat 8/9, and premium tasked imagery—you get a clear, consistent view of crop development from 2019 onward. Advanced denoising and smoothing techniques remove atmospheric and sensor noise, revealing the true biological signal of the crop.

For deeper historical patterns and long-term benchmarking, tap into our low-resolution imagery time series, powered by denoised and smoothed MODIS data dating back to 2003. The planned integration of Sentinel-3 will ensure monitoring continuity while maintaining full cross-calibration with MODIS.

Together, these datasets allow you to analyze multi-season patterns, detect shifts in vigor across years, and uncover insights that support more informed management strategies.

docs.title: 🗺️ Maps to Analyze Field Variability
docs.text:
The Digital Ag solution provides Vegetation Field-level Maps to help you understand in-field variability with clarity and precision. These maps reveal spatial differences in vigor, nutrition, moisture, and canopy structure across every field—enabling you to pinpoint hotspots, identify within-field zones, and target interventions where they will have the greatest impact.

Add even more context with integrated soil maps (including SSURGO-based layers for the U.S.) and detailed elevation and slope models, giving you a full understanding of terrain, risks, and management opportunities across every acre.

Identify emerging issues at a glance with our HotSpot Processor, highlighting areas that are changing and may require immediate attention—ensuring you never miss a developing problem and can act quickly.

To keep your workflow seamless, save your go-to layers with Favorite Maps—complete with your preferred parameters—so you can pull up the right view in seconds.

docs.title: 📊 Weather Indicators to Understand Climatic Conditions
docs.text:
The Digital Ag solution provides access to weather indicators—daily and cumulative precipitation, temperature, GDD, and more—to understand growth patterns and see how your conditions compare to previous years.

As a result, you get a clear, reliable picture of crop vigor across space and time—capturing how fields respond to weather events and seasonal conditions. Imagery time series and weather data form the foundational inputs for many agronomic and AI modeling approaches, providing both the long-term context and short-term precision needed to anticipate issues.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: 👥 Let Our Customers Speak for Themselves
SOYL
docs.text:
“The technology enhances our existing biomass imagery model so that growers using the service can receive regular, high-quality, cloud-free images throughout the key winter cereal nitrogen application window.”

SOYL is a leading precision crop production service provider. Based in the U.K., SOYL’s software technology is in use in more than 15 countries worldwide.

Poor weather can be a major challenge for satellite monitoring of crop growth. Cloud cover can obscure imagery, limiting growers’ access to essential information about crop development and performance.

The radar imagery designed by EarthDaily Analytics improved monitoring of SOYL's fields during periods of poor visibility. The radar model successfully passed a three-season test period with the company’s quality approval before full implementation.

To build on this success, SOYL also began utilizing NDVI, CVI, and automated LAI analytics from EarthDaily Agro to produce variable-rate maps based on scientifically adjusted models. To ensure quality, SOYL provides ground truth measurements each year to calibrate their model and adapt it to each season.

Ready to learn more? Our team is available to discuss how EarthDaily's agricultural intelligence platform can meet your specific needs. Contact us

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This analytic automatically generates field boundaries based on point coordinates (longitude and latitude). The feature is accessible via both the API and the GeosysApp. Postman collection is available. Your account requires specific permissions to access this API. Please contact us to request access.

docs.title: 📖 Overview
docs.text:
EarthDailyAgro's Environmental Compliance Report analytic enables Brazilian customers to quickly check whether or not a given geometry (1) (field, farm, policy or other) complies with environmental and national legislation. The user provides at least a geometry in WKT (2) format and a CPF (3) or CNPJ (4) number, and they can retrieve the report in JSON and PDF format, with all intersection percentages if any.

The Environmental Compliance Report is a tool that guides analysis based on federal and state-level geospatial data from Brazilian public institutes. Its goal is to reduce environmental risks by identifying overlap with embargoes, historical deforestation, and protected territories such as native land, permanent protection areas, legal reserves, etc. Easy to apply, it is widely used by financial agents, banks, and insurance companies.

docs.title: AOI (Area of Interest)
docs.text: User-defined area for analysis. Usually defined as WKT.

docs.title: WKT (Well-Known Text)
docs.text: Standard format for representing spatial geometries such as polygons, points, and lines.

docs.title: CPF (Cadastro de Pessoa Física)
docs.text: Brazilian individual taxpayer registry number issued by the Federal Revenue Service. Used to identify natural persons.

docs.title: CNPJ (Cadastro Nacional da Pessoa Jurídica)
docs.text: Brazilian company (legal entity) taxpayer registry number issued by the Federal Revenue Service. Used to identify organizations and companies.

docs.title: 🗂️ Baseline Data
docs.text:
The compliance analysis uses comprehensive geospatial datasets from Brazilian federal and state agencies. These include CAR (5) property boundaries, SIGEF (6) and SNCI (7) land registries managed by INCRA (8), conservation areas from ICMBio (9), and embargo lists from IBAMA (10) and state environmental agencies including SEMA-MT (11), SIGA-GO (12), SIGA-MT (13), IAT-PR (14), and the LDI-PA (15) deforestation list.

Detailed description of each dataset is available on the Environmental Layers page.

docs.title: CAR (Cadastro Ambiental Rural)
docs.text: Brazilian national public registry integrating environmental information about rural properties, including farm boundaries and environmental features.

docs.title: SIGEF (Sistema de Gestão Fundiária)
docs.text: Land Management System developed by INCRA to register and validate georeferenced rural property data.

docs.title: SNCI (Sistema Nacional de Cadastro de Imóveis Rurais)
docs.text: National Property Certification System developed by INCRA to manage cadastral and geospatial data of rural properties.

docs.title: INCRA (Instituto Nacional de Colonização e Reforma Agrária)
docs.text: Federal agency responsible for land reform, land management, and maintaining Brazilian national land databases such as SIGEF and SNCI.

docs.title: ICMBio (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade)
docs.text: Federal agency responsible for managing Brazil's conservation units and biodiversity preservation.

docs.title: IBAMA (Instituto Brasileiro do Meio Ambiente e dos Recursos Naturais Renováveis)
docs.text: Federal environmental agency in charge of environmental law enforcement, licensing, and conservation at the national level.

docs.title: SEMA-MT (Secretaria de Estado de Meio Ambiente de Mato Grosso)
docs.text: State Secretariat for the Environment in Mato Grosso, responsible for environmental regulation and enforcement.

docs.title: SIGA-GO (Sistema de Gestão Ambiental de Goiás)
docs.text: State environmental management system for Goiás, used to track infractions, embargoes, and environmental compliance.

docs.title: SIGA-MT (Sistema Integrado de Gestão Ambiental de Mato Grosso)
docs.text: State environmental management system for Mato Grosso.

docs.title: IAT-PR (Instituto Água e Terra do Paraná)
docs.text: Environmental institute of Paraná responsible for licensing, monitoring, and conservation activities.

docs.title: LDI-PA (Lista de Desmatamento Ilegal do Pará)
docs.text: Official list of farms with illegal deforestation in the state of Pará.
